ai_content: Tips for Protecting Yourself and Others from COVID-19 COVID-19, or coronavirus disease 2019, is a new virus that is primarily transmitted from person to person. While scientists and doctors are still learning about the virus, it has already made many people sick. To protect yourself and those around you from COVID-19, there are several steps you can take. First, stay informed by keeping in touch with your case workers, group home staff, or shelter staff. They can provide you with updates on the situation and advise you on what to do. Second, practice good hygiene. Wash your hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after being in public places or touching surfaces that other people may have touched. Avoid touching your face, especially your eyes, nose, and mouth. Third, practice social distancing by staying at least six feet away from other people. Avoid crowded places and gatherings, especially if you are at higher risk of getting sick. Fourth, wear a mask or face covering when you are in public places. This can help prevent the spread of the virus, especially if you are asymptomatic. Finally, if you feel sick or have symptoms of COVID-19, such as fever, cough, or difficulty breathing, stay home and seek medical advice. By taking these steps, you can help protect yourself and others from COVID-19.

ai_content: WHO airlifts 20-tonne medical supplies to Beirut blast victims A shipment of 20 tonnes of medical supplies from the World Health Organization (WHO) has arrived in Beirut, Lebanon. The supplies are intended to treat patients injured by the massive blast that occurred in the city on 4 August. ai_content: Assessing Workplace Scenarios to Limit Spread of COVID-19 Workers and management must work together to identify scenarios in the workplace where it is difficult to maintain social distancing of at least 6 feet. A committee comprising workers and management may be the most effective way to recognize all such scenarios. The next step is to use a combination of controls, following the hierarchy of controls, to address these situations and limit the spread of the virus that causes COVID-19. It is important to note that while protecting workers, control recommendations or interventions to reduce the spread of the virus must not create new hazards or exacerbate existing ones. The hierarchy of controls should be followed, starting with engineering controls such as installing physical barriers or increasing ventilation. Administrative controls such as staggered work schedules or limiting the number of workers on-site can also be used to reduce the risk of transmission. Personal protective equipment (PPE) such as masks and gloves should be used as a last resort when other controls are not feasible or effective. However, PPE should not be used as a substitute for other controls. By working together and using appropriate controls, workers and management can help limit the spread of COVID-19 in the workplace and keep workers safe.
